title: 108_hr2601
content: The "Public Domain Enhancement Act" may be cited as the short title of this legislation. The Congress finds that the copyright clause in the United States Constitution grants Congress the power to promote the progress of science and useful arts by securing exclusive rights to authors for limited times. This serves two purposes: providing economic incentives for authors to create new works and promoting society's interest in the free flow of ideas, information, and commerce. The copyright term is limited to prevent permanent deprivation of the fruits of an artist's labor. Both commercial and noncommercial creators rely on a healthy public domain for various purposes such as publishing titles at reduced prices, creating new productions, and producing educational materials. Under current law, copyright protection is granted to works published as early as 1923, but the majority of older works are no longer commercially available. Only 2 percent of works between 55 and 75 years old retain commercial value. This prevents abandoned works from entering the public domain for many years, limiting access for commercial and noncommercial entities. The existing copyright system hinders the entry of abandoned works into the public domain, contrary to the original intent of the Constitution and the Copyright Act. A mechanism is needed to allow abandoned American copyrights to enter the public domain. SEC. 3. MAINTENANCE FEE FOR PUBLISHED UNITED STATES WORKS. The definition of "United States work" in section 101 of title 17, United States Code, is amended for sections 306 and 411. Section 302 of title 17 is amended for works created on or after January 1, 1978, regarding the duration of copyright. Section 303(a) of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include provisions related to copyright and section 306. Subsection (a) of Section 304 is also amended to include provisions related to section 306 for subsisting copyrights. Section 303(a) of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include provisions related to copyright and section 306. Subsection (a) of Section 304 is also amended to include provisions related to section 306 for subsisting copyrights. In subparagraph (C), "In" is replaced with "Subject to section 306, in". Subsection (b) is modified by replacing "Any" with "Subject to section 306, any". Maintenance Fee is also addressed. The Register of Copyrights shall charge a $1 fee for maintaining the copyright in any published United States work. The fee is due 50 years after first publication or on December 31, 2004, and every 10 years thereafter. Failure to pay the fee within 6 months of the due date will result in the copyright expiring. The copyright maintenance fee for published United States works is $1 and is due 50 years after first publication or on December 31, 2004, and every 10 years thereafter. Ancillary and promotional works connected to the maintained copyright are also covered. The fee must be accompanied by a prescribed form and additional materials as required by the Register of Copyrights. The maintenance fee for published United States works is $1 and is due 50 years after first publication or on December 31, 2004, and every 10 years thereafter. Ancillary and promotional works connected to the maintained copyright are also covered. The fee must be accompanied by a prescribed form and additional materials as required by the Register of Copyrights. Section 708(a) of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include the maintenance fee under section 306. The Register of Copyrights must establish procedures to ease the submission of forms under section 306(c) of title 17, US Code, and make the information easily accessible to the public within 12 months of this Act's enactment.
